description:
A quiet gothic horror story about a vampire girl, Miyu, whose destiny it is to hunt down murderous demons known as Shinma and return them to their land of origin, the Dark. Miyu is pursued by the Spiritualist Himiko, determined to find out who Miyu is and to stop her from sucking the life blood from helpless humans. Each of the four episodes chronicle one of Miyu's encounters with a Shinma and the humans that it is affecting, from the perspective of Himiko's pursuit of Miyu.

(Source: AniDB)
synonyms: ヴァンパイア ミユ

tags.name: Vampire
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a vampire.

tags.name: Time Skip
tags.description: Features a gap in time used to advance the story.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Cosmic Horror
tags.description: A type of horror that emphasizes human insignificance in the grand scope of cosmic reality; fearing the unknown and being powerless to fight it.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: Body Horror
tags.description: Features characters who undergo horrific transformations or disfigurement, often to their own detriment.

tags.name: Gods
tags.description: Prominently features a character of divine or religious nature.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Urban Fantasy
tags.description: Set in a world similar to the real world, but with the existence of magic or other supernatural elements.

tags.name: Afterlife
tags.description: Partly or completely set in the afterlife.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

node.description:
She is a mangaka, animator, director, character designer, and an animation director. Some of her work has appeared in the adult manga magazine Lemon People.

After graduating from high school, she began working at Studio Beebo under the direction of Tomonori Kogawa, then moving on to Studio Io, Artland, AIC and other studios where she was an animator, designer, and animation director on many TV series and OVAs. She made her manga and character designer debut with Vampire Princess Miyu. Due to her magnificent artwork, she became very popular even outside the anime and manga scene, doing illustrations and character designs for many other projects.

Kakinouchi is married to anime director [Toshiki Hirano](https://anilist.co/staff/97477/Toshiki-Hirano).

(Source: AniDB)

[Website](http://www.kenjikawai.com/index_e.html) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%B7%9D%E4%BA%95%E6%86%B2%E6%AC%A1)

After dropping out of a nuclear engineering program at Tokai University, Kawai Kenji began studying music at Shobi Music Academy. However, he dropped out after half a year. With a few friends, he created the band Muse, playing fusion rock and participating in music competitions. Through competing in such contests, the band members became technically competent to enter the music industry and decided to part ways.

After leaving Muse, Kawai Kenji began composing music for commercials in his home studio. While recording music for [Yuji Mitsuya](https://anilist.co/staff/95874/) he met music director Naoko Asari, who advised him to compose anime soundtracks. Some of his most famous anime soundtracks can be found in [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/1288/), [Ranma ½](https://anilist.co/anime/210/), [Ghost in the Shell](https://anilist.co/anime/43/), [Fate/Stay Night](https://anilist.co/anime/356/), [When They Cry](https://anilist.co/anime/934/) and more recently in [Mob Psycho 100](https://anilist.co/anime/21507/).

He has worked on several projects with the director [Mamoru Oshii](https://anilist.co/staff/99097/) and has written scores for all of Hideo Nakata's films. Kenji Kawai's music has received the Annie award and Hong Kong Film Award in 2005, for [Ghost in The Shell 2: Innocence](https://anilist.co/anime/468/) he was nominated for an Annie award.

Following his success as an anime music composer, he became involved in live action movies. He contributed music to horror films: Ring, Ring 2, Dark Water, Japanese-Polish science-fiction film Avalon and the Hong Kong film Seven Swords.

For the music found in Seven Swords and A Battle of Wits he was nominated for Best Original Film Score Awards at both the 25th and 26th Hong Kong Film Awards in 2006 and 2007.

(Source: AniDB)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/北爪宏幸)

His representative works include [Mobile Suit Gundam ZZ](https://anilist.co/anime/86/), [Char's Counterattack](https://anilist.co/anime/87/) and [Moldiver](https://anilist.co/anime/571/).

Retired from the anime industry in the early 2000s and has since worked on manga.

He is an animator and character designer. Motohashi started working at Studio Z. Later, after leaving Studio Z, he started together with Hirayama Satoshi and Kamegaki Hajime Studio Z5. Today he is affiliated with Xebec and is the representative director of its subsidiary Xebec M2.

Affiliated with [J.C. Staff](https://anilist.co/studio/7/).

Sakurabi made his directional debut with [Gunparade March](https://anilist.co/anime/266/). He is a fan of simple and refreshing love stories. As a director he's known for modifying original stories a lot, which has brought him substantial amounts of critique. He is quite infamous for his work as the director of the [Tsukihime](https://anilist.co/anime/169/) adaptation, with most fans disapproving of his changes from the original visual novel.

Amongst his most notable directorial works are [Yomigaeru Sora: Rescue Wings](https://anilist.co/anime/798/) and [Flying Witch](https://anilist.co/anime/21284/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/新井浩一)

One of the founders of [Kinema Citrus](https://anilist.co/studio/290/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/AnimEigo)

Founder of [AnimEigo](https://anilist.co/studio/310/) along with Roe R. Adams III. Husband of [Natsumi Ueki](https://anilist.co/staff/202473/)
Was a Translator at AnimEigo and then worked for Gainax.
Founder of background art studio Kusanagi.

She is a mangaka, animator, director, character designer, and an animation director. Some of her work has appeared in the adult manga magazine Lemon People.

After graduating from high school, she began working at Studio Beebo under the direction of Tomonori Kogawa, then moving on to Studio Io, Artland, AIC and other studios where she was an animator, designer, and animation director on many TV series and OVAs. She made her manga and character designer debut with Vampire Princess Miyu. Due to her magnificent artwork, she became very popular even outside the anime and manga scene, doing illustrations and character designs for many other projects.

Kakinouchi is married to anime director [Toshiki Hirano](https://anilist.co/staff/97477/Toshiki-Hirano).

(Source: AniDB)

Miura Tooru is the founder and former president of AIC. He was born in Tokyo, Japan.

(Source: AniDB)
